subtitle: Hello, I'm JeffreyMishlove and today I'm
going to respond to a viewer request
that I talk about alcohol,
which seems fitting because it's just been
a few days since I addressed the
question of psychedelics. As I think
about it, I realize that I could divide
my own life into two phases, one being
before psychedelics and the other being
after. I include marijuana here
as a mild psychedelic. But, the point is
that I had a life before psychedelics
and it was a life filled with alcohol.
You see, growing up in Wisconsin, as I did
in the 1960s, I graduated from high
school in 1965, from LP Goodrich High
School in Fond du Lac, Wisconsin.
Honestly, I don't know if it's still
true, but at that time it felt as if it
was our patriotic duty to drink lots of
milk during the week. Because after all,
Wisconsin is the dairy state. In fact, in
Wisconsin, if you go to a restaurant
and order a piece of apple pie, you are
legally required, if you should request
it, to be entitled to a piece of cheddar
cheese with that apple pie. The beer
industry in Wisconsin during my high
school years was really big, next to the
dairy industry. I suspect it was the
largest industry in Wisconsin. So, it was
virtually a patriotic duty to get drunk
every weekend. I'm referring you to, like,
my whole high school class. It was big,
drinking, drinking was very big.
Underage drinking was big too. At the age
of 16, I already had established a fake
ID for myself and was using it to get
into taverns and to drink beer,
because In those days in Wisconsin, you
could drink
beer legally at the age of 18, and hard
liquor legally at the age of 21. But, from
the age of even under 16 and onward, beer
was just a regular part of my life. I
remember on one occasion, as a matter of
fact, a keg party with a keg of beer, I
was maybe fifteen, maybe even fourteen as I recall,
and it was hosted by my aunt, my saintly
aunt Jeanette, as a matter of fact. I
think it's the first time I got drunk,
was then. But, it became a regular
thing for me and my friends in high
school to drink beer on the weekends. We
learned to go to the best places. You could
drive about 10-15 miles out of town
and there was a bar out in the country that
would serve you a glass of beer for ten
cents. We would drive out there
and frankly get plastered. I'm talking
about in the middle of winter in
Wisconsin when the roads are icy. I
developed a talent for holding my liquor,
yes, and for driving drunk through ice
and snow in the Wisconsin win
ter. I loved it. I love that life, but honestly
it was terribly reckless. I can
tell you today, how many lives I know of
that have been tragically ruined because
of alcohol. I'm very fortunate to have
escaped that in my life. I attribute it
to good luck or good karma, perhaps also
just a certain natural ability. But in
any case, alcohol has caused, overall,
enormous amount of suffering in our
country. You know, my high school days
were before the existence of Mothers
Against Drunk Driving. But, there was
a drunk driver who actually totaled the car
that I had. It was
parked out in front of our house one
winter evening and in the morning I got
up and saw that the car had been
dented very severely, and learned
that it was done by a drunk driver in
the middle of the night. I have a
brother-in-law who drank himself to
death. I've had high school classmates
killed in accidents due to drunk driving.
In fact, the night of the senior class
banquet in my high school, a carload, I
think of 6 high school kids
driving back into town from out in the
country where I know there was one of
those bars where you could drink a lot,
and they got into an accident. Everyone
was killed. I know of another dear friend
of mine, Native American, who married a
beautiful woman. After they were married, she
had one drink of alcohol, and after that
she was addicted for life, seriously,
major addiction. Now, I think a certain
amount of that is genetic. My
understanding is that American Indians
are perhaps more prone to suffer
addiction to alcohol. I think Jewish
people are less prone, but that's an
accident of genetics. But, let's talk
about the experience of being high. One
of the most interesting things that I
observed from alcohol is that after I
began using marijuana and psychedelics,
alcohol became a little different
because, well, at that point I was on a
path, a quest, for self-knowledge. I
discovered that if I had a beer
and smoked marijuana at the same time, the
beer affected me differently. It would
really just sort of amplify and to
some extent, maybe took the edge a bit
off of the marijuana. That, either one
of them could help bring back a feeling
of being
like high on a major psychedelic. Once you've
had that experience, you can trigger it
again with substances like marijuana
and alcohol depending of course, on the set
and setting. Now, this may seem ironic, but
one of the major, I think, positive
benefits that has come out of alcohol
use in our culture is the establishment
of Alcoholics Anonymous and 12-step
programs. My understanding is that, I
believe the name is Bill W., the founder
of Alcoholics Anonymous, someone who
really has chosen to remain anonymous.
But, he was a student both of the works
of Carl Jung and of William James. A
lot of their thinking went into the
development of the 12-step program. It's
now used not just for alcoholics, but for
all sorts of addictions. As best I
can tell, [it] appears to be one of the
most effective programs for
treating those conditions. So that's a
plus. And I have to say, millions of
people enjoy alcohol everyday. It's a
huge industry. It's a gigantic
market. If most people have
experiences like mine, it's relatively
benign. But for a minority of people, it
is a very dangerous drug. The
social consequences of alcohol are as
serious as for any other drug that's
being used in our culture, and I'm
talking about heroin and amphetamines. I
would say that overall alcohol is
probably just as dangerous, even though
for many people, such as myself, it's not
really much of a problem, which isn't to
say that I haven't on occasion abused
alcohol.
Indeed, I have. And maybe it's something
that many young people need to go
through when you're that young
and you think you're invulnerable, you
have to learn your limits. But I do
remember on one occasion, after what we called
a wapatuli party, which is really a
horrible thing, where you have a big
punch bowl and people come to the party
bringing whatever bottles of liquor or
booze that they happen to have, and it
all gets poured in together in the punch
bowl. It was a wild party. I
remember waking up, it was at a summer
resort, and I found myself waking up on
the ground somewhere in that resort,
sleeping on top of a pool of my own
vomit. So, yes, that happened to me.
It happened once and once only. But I
did, I discovered my limit at that point.
These days, I don't drink much at all.
One of the reasons is that my
cardiologist, I've had heart issues,
and my cardiologist suggested to avoid
alcohol completely. He said there was a
major study, 50,000 people long-term,
and it was shown in that study that alcohol
use could exacerbate various heart
conditions like an arrhythmia, which I
had at the time. I don't have it anymore
since I've had an ablation, at least it's
almost completely gone. But the point
being, the cardiologists said, "Stop
drinking." And I thought to myself, I'm
going to read that study, because I enjoy
alcohol. I wasn't really inclined to stop
drinking completely. I read it and it
was correct, but for the fact that it
seemed as if beer drinking didn't
have that effect. Every other type of
alcohol did. So, now when I have alcohol,
almost entirely it's an occasional
beer. Generally never more than
one beer per day and not enough to even
really
feel high at all, just maybe a little
mellow. So, that's my use of alcohol. But,
so sure, I've shared a bit of my life
with you. But, I always want to come back
to the question, what's in this for you,
because learning about my experiences
growing up in Wisconsin in the 1960s, it
may be interesting and entertaining for
you, but it doesn't leave you with much.
So, let me ask you this question, what has
alcohol use been like for you? Has it
been good? Do you enjoy alcohol? Have you
ever abused alcohol?
Are you currently abusing alcohol? And be
honest with yourself about it, because I
know that one of the symptoms of alcohol
abuse is called cognitive dysfunction, so
you could abuse alcohol and tell yourself
that you're not. I've seen that. I've
seen it on a number of occasions with
alcoholics and alcohol abusers who are
in denial. It's a very serious issue. So,
ask yourself if you could do better than
you are with regard to alcohol. I know
some people spend a lot of money on it.
You could buy very expensive
wines and liqueurs if you want. You
might ask yourself if that's a good
expenditure for you. I'm really not here
to lecture you or tell you what to do.
I've made enough mistakes on my own
and I've been lucky to have avoided even
more serious mistakes. But, I would
encourage you to ask yourself these
questions. And once again, thank you for
being with me.
